{{for|the Mexican telenovela|Martín Garatuza (telenovela)}} {{citations needed|date=September 2014}} '''Martín Garatuza''' (born 1601, [[Puebla]], [[Mexico]]) was a famous trickster whose frauds and escapes became legendary in colonial [[New Spain]] and whose name has passed into Spanish language, folklore and literature.
Garatuza, whose real name was Martín de Villavicencio Salazar, came to the attention of the authorities in Puebla in 1640 for posing as a priest without having been ordained. He played this role with great pomp, offering his hand to be kissed, hearing confessions, and saying mass. In this way he travelled through much of New Spain, gaining his living fraudulently.
In 1642 he was arrested in [[Nejapa de Madero|Nejapa]], [[Oaxaca]] by the [[Inquisition]], accused of saying mass without being ordained. He managed to escape, but a few months later he turned himself in to the Inquisition in Mexico City. He soon talked his way out of detention, being granted a leave of 40 days to return to Puebla for health reasons. Naturally, he used this opportunity to escape again and continue his escapades.
He was apprehended a third time and condemned to appear in an [[auto de fe]] "as a penitent, with a green candle in his hands, a rope about his neck, a white hood on his head". He was to receive 200 lashes and was sentenced to the galleys of [[Ternate|Terrenate]] for five years without pay. The auto de fe was held March 30, 1648 in Mexico City. Thereafter he left New Spain to complete his sentence and was never heard from again.
The expression "¿En qué pararán estas misas, Garatuza?" (What will end these masses, Garatuza?) has passed into the language. It refers to a difficult position a person finds himself in through the consequences of his own actions. The word ''gartusa'' (note the variant spelling) has several meanings as a noun. There is a card game of that name. The word can also mean the use of cajolery and flattery to gain one's ends, and it is the name of a feint in fencing.
[[Vicente Riva Palacio]] (1832–96) wrote the novel ''Martín Gartuza''. There is also a Mexican movie based on this novel (1935). In 1986 a Mexican telenovela of the same name was broadcast.
He is remembered in Mexico as a humorous character, one who lived by his wits but did not use violence.
==References== *{{es icon}} "Garatuza, Martín," ''Enciclopedia de México'', v. 6. Mexico City, 1988. *{{es icon}} Alvarez, Luis Rodrigo, ''Historia General del Estado de Oaxaca''. Oaxaca: Carteles, 1995.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Garatuza, Martin}} [[Category:1601 births]] [[Category:People from Puebla]] [[Category:Colonial Mexico]] [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:Year of death missing]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Mo Pop Festival | image = | caption = | location = West Riverfront Park
[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | founders = | years_active = 2013–present | dates = 2-day weekend in July | genre = [[Indie rock]], [[pop music|pop]], and [[hip hop music|hip hop]] | website = {{URL|http://mopopfestival.com}} | attendance = 7,500–20,000 }} The '''Mo Pop Festival''' is a [[music festival]] in [[Detroit]]. The festival features both emerging as well as established musicians, and its ambiance has been described as "boutique and niche".{{Cite news|url=https://www.metrotimes.com/detroit/mo-pop-so-pretty-so-boutique-and-so-niche/Content?oid=2456361|title=Mo Pop: so pretty, so boutique, and so niche|last=Roskopp|first=Jack|date=July 20, 2016|work=[[Detroit Metro Times]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} It showcases [[indie rock|indie-rock]], [[pop music|pop]], and [[hip hop music|hip-hop]] music along with local Detroit cuisine and beverages, in addition to endeavoring to bring visitors to the city's [[Detroit International Riverfront|riverfront]]. Though smaller in size, Mo Pop has been compared to other musical festivals such as [[Bonnaroo Music Festival|Bonnaroo]], [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella]], [[Lollapalooza]], and [[Pitchfork Music Festival|Pitchfork]]. It has also drawn comparisons to other festivals held in the city, namely the [[Detroit Jazz Festival]] and [[Movement Electronic Music Festival]]. == History == === Freedom Hill Amphitheatre in Sterling Heights (2013–2014) === The inaugural 2013 Mo Pop Festival was held on a single day at the Freedom Hill Amphitheatre in suburban [[Sterling Heights, Michigan|Sterling Heights]]. It featured performances by [[Andrew Bird]], [[Capital Cities (band)|Capital Cities]], [[Jamaican Queens]], [[JR JR]], [[Manchester Orchestra]], [[The Mowgli's]], [[Old Crow Medicine Show]], [[Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros]], [[Walk off the Earth]], and [[Wild Belle]].{{Cite web|url=http://chevydetroit.com/mo-pop-festival-freedom-hill-ampitheatre/|title=Mo Pop Festival|date=2013|publisher=Metro Detroit Chevy Dealers|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 24, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.livenation.com/events/250300-aug-17-2013-mo-pop-festival|title=Mo Pop Festival|date=August 17, 2013|publisher=[[Live Nation Entertainment|Live Nation]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 24, 2018}} The 2014 festival, also held at Freedom Hill, staggered set times to allow attendees to watch all musical acts, and it featured performances by [[City and Colour]], [[Cold War Kids]], [[Flint Eastwood]], [[J Roddy Walston and the Business]], [[Lord Huron]], [[Tokyo Police Club]], and [[Young the Giant]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.sound-andsilence.com/mo-pop-music-festival-at-freedom-hill.html|title=MO POP Music Festival at Freedom Hill|last=Solecki|first=Ryan|date=July 17, 2014|work=Sound & Silence|access-date=March 24, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Both the 2013 and 2014 festivals were attended by approximately 7,500 people. After the 2014 festival, Mo Pop looked to move to Detroit due to both its location and to enable further growth, according to festival co-producer Jason Rogalewski. === West Riverfront Park in Detroit (2015–present) === ==== 2015 ==== The 2015 Mo Pop Festival was the first to be held at West Riverfront Park in Detroit, just west of [[Downtown Detroit|Downtown]], and also the first two-day festival.{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/07/30/mo-pop-festival-2017-review/523426001/|title=Mo Pop Festival 2017: Opening day teems with musical treats in Detroit|last=McCollum|first=Brian|date=July 30, 2017|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/04/02/mo-pop-expands-two-days-moves-detroit-riverfront/70820262/|title=Mo Pop expands to two days, moves to Detroit riverfront|last=Graham|first=Adam|date=April 2, 2015|work=[[The Detroit News]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Held on July 25–26, it was headlined by [[Modest Mouse]] and [[Passion Pit]], and also featured performances by [[Atlas Genius]], [[James Bay (singer)|James Bay]], [[Chromeo]], [[Brandon Flowers]], [[Jessica Hernandez & the Deltas]], [[Iron & Wine]], [[King Tuff]], and [[Viet Cong (band)|Viet Cong]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/07/17/mo-pop-reboot-west-riverfront/30318011/|title=Mo Pop reboots at West Riverfront with indie rock, art|last=McCollum|first=Brian|date=July 18, 2015|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/brian-mccollum/2015/04/02/mo-pop-detroit-details/70805780/|title=Modest Mouse, Passion Pit lead expanded Mo Pop fest|last=McCollum|first=Brian|date=April 1, 2015|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} West Riverfront Park is a {{Convert|20|acre|ha|adj=on}} park on the [[Detroit River]] with views of the downtown skyline and the [[Ambassador Bridge]], and it was created in 2014 by Detroit's Riverfront Conservancy on the site of a former ''Detroit Free Press'' printing facility. Described as "free-spirited" and "whimsically themed", Mo Pop's 2015 iteration once again featured two stages aligned so that attendees could watch both without physically moving, and alternated time slots between so they would not have to choose between acts performing simultaneously. In addition to music, the 2015 festival also included [[artisan]]s and craft makers, [[visual arts|visual artists]], [[microbrewery|craft beer]], [[food truck]]s, and even a Mo Tech village "showcasing work from local start-ups and inventors". During the festival, heavy rainfall overwhelmed the park's drainage capabilities and formed a standing body of water nicknamed "Lake Mo Pop".{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/07/26/mo-pop-festival-2017/510979001/|title=Now in 5th year, Mo Pop eager to expand Detroit presence|last=Reimink|first=Troy|date=July 26, 2017|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/07/16/mo-pop-festival-preview/87094154/|title=Mo Pop fest returns to riverfront, plans for drier times|last=Reimink|first=Troy|date=July 16, 2016|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Mo Pop's 2015 total two-day attendance was estimated to be over 15,000. ==== 2016 ==== The 2016 Mo Pop Festival, held on July 24–25 at West Riverfront Park for the second year, was headlined by [[Børns]], [[G-Eazy]], [[Haim (band)|Haim]], [[The Head and the Heart]], and [[M83 (band)|M83]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/07/24/mo-pop-festival-detroit/87486030/|title=Hot day on the riverfront gets cool with Mo Pop fest|last=McCollum|first=Brian|date=July 24, 2016|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} It also featured performances by [[Coast Modern]], [[Mac DeMarco]], [[Glass Animals]], [[Matt and Kim]], [[Father John Misty]], and [[Panama Wedding]]. It drew an attendance of over 20,000 people over its two days. New for 2016 was a tented [[arcade game|arcade]] and games area, and a "craft village" vendor area. ==== 2017 ==== The 2017 Mo Pop Festival, held on July 29–30 at West Riverfront Park, was headlined by [[Alt-J]], [[Foster the People]], [[Run the Jewels]], and [[Solange Knowles|Solange]]. Other acts included [[Vance Joy]], [[Middle Kids]], [[Grace Mitchell]], [[Phantogram (band)|Phantogram]], [[PUP (band)|PUP]], [[PVRIS]], [[Tyler, the Creator]], and [[Wavves]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/03/22/mo-pop-2017-detroit-run-the-jewels-alt-j-solange-/99467586/|title=Mo Pop 2017 lineup: Run the Jewels, Alt-J, Solange coming to Detroit|last=McCollum|first=Brian|date=March 22, 2017|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.clickondetroit.com/entertainment/mo-pop-festival-detroit-2017-alt-j-foster-the-people-run-the-jewels-headline|title=Mo Pop Festival Detroit 2017: Alt-J, Foster The People, Run The Jewels headline|last=Haddad|first=Ken|date=March 22, 2017|publisher=[[WDIV-TV]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.metrotimes.com/city-slang/archives/2017/06/28/mo-pop-reveals-2017-set-times-adds-singer-grace-mitchell-to-lineup|title=Mo Pop reveals 2017 set times, adds singer Grace Mitchell to lineup|last=Roskopp|first=Jack|date=June 28, 2017|work=[[Detroit Metro Times]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.theoaklandpress.com/arts-and-entertainment/20170731/mo-pop-day-2-solange-and-alt-j-rock-the-park|title=Mo Pop day 2, Solange and Alt-J rock the park|last=Steingold|first=Eric|date=July 31, 2017|work=[[The Oakland Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Bermudez|first2=Michael}} Both days of the festival started with back-to-back Michigan artists, including [[Stef Chura]] and [[Heaters (band)|Heaters]]. In total, the 2017 iteration of Mo Pop featured over nine hours of music with musicians on two different stages. It also included a dozen local food trucks and the Shipyard, a food and beverage court that was presented by [[Corktown, Detroit|Corktown]]'s cocktail bar Sugar House and featured barbecue from [[Slows Bar BQ]], hot dogs and tacos from [[Ferndale, Michigan|Ferndale]]'s Imperial restaurant, craft beers from [[Birmingham, Michigan|Birmingham]]'s Griffin Claw Brewing Company, and adult ciders from Blake's Hard Cider Company of [[Armada, Michigan|Armada]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/dining/2017/07/10/mo-pop-festival-offers-exclusive-food-drink-experience/103580414/|title=Mo Pop offers exclusive food and drink experience|last=Baetens|first=Melody|date=July 10, 2017|work=[[The Detroit News]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} ==== 2018 ==== The 2018 Mo Pop Festival, scheduled for July 28–29, will be headlined by [[Bon Iver]], [[The National (band)|The National]], [[Portugal. The Man]], and [[St. Vincent (musician)|St. Vincent]]. It will be the fourth straight festival at West Riverfront Park. Also performing will be [[Brockhampton (band)|Brockhampton]], [[Highly Suspect]], [[Vince Staples]], and the Detroit-based band [[Joe Hertler & The Rainbow Seekers]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/03/07/mo-pop-festival-2018-linupe/400397002/|title=Mo Pop Festival reveals 2018 lineup: Rare Bon Iver set, the National, St. Vincent|last=McCollum|first=Brian|date=March 7, 2018|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.detroitnews.com/story/entertainment/people/2018/03/07/grapevine-mo-pop-festival-lineup-released/32714199/|title=Grapevine: Mo Pop Festival lineup released|last=Baetens|first=Melody|date=March 7, 2018|work=[[The Detroit News]]|access-date=March 22, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://mopopfestival.com/index.html}} * {{Facebook|MoPopFestival}} * {{Twitter|MoPopFestival}} * {{Instagram|mopopfestival}} [[Category:Music festivals in Michigan]] [[Category:Rock festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Pop music festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Hip hop music festivals]] [[Category:Events in Detroit]] [[Category:Music of Detroit]] [[Category:2013 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 2013]]

{{infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = Old Settler's Music Festival | image = OldSettlersMusicFestival2010.jpg | caption= Old Settler's Music Festival in 2010 | location = [[Austin, Texas]] | years_active=1987–present | founded_by = | dates = April | genre = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Traditional music|roots]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Country music|country]] | website = {{URL|http://oldsettlersmusicfest.org}} }}
'''Old Settler's Music Festival''' is an annual [[music festival]] held since 1988. The festival dates for 2019 are April 11th to the 14th in Tilmon Texas, just southeast of Lockhart, Texas. As one of Central Texas' signature music events, the festival features acoustic jazz and blues, bluegrass, local favorites, and award-winning artists from around the world.<ref>[http://www.kxan.com/dpp/news/local/old-settlers-music-festival-amps-up KXAN]</ref> Camping, arts and crafts, food and drink are available.<ref>[http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/music/entries/old_settlers_music_festival/ Austin American Statesman]</ref>
The festival is represented at numerous music events including the International Folk Alliance Conference, the Americana Music Festival & Conference, South By South West, the International Bluegrass Music Festival's World of Bluegrass, and the International Music Festival Conference.
==History== The Old Settler's Bluegrass Festival was first held in Old Settler's Park in Round Rock, Texas. After the park flooded during a festival weekend, the organizers moved the festival first to Stone Mountain Events Center in Dripping Springs, Texas, and later to the Salt Lick BBQ Pavilion and Camp Ben McCulloch in Driftwood, Texas. In 2018, the festival moved to it's forever home on 145 acres of rolling meadows and tree covered campgrounds. The new location is just a cd's worth of listening from Austin. The name of the festival was modified to Old Settler's Music Festival in 2000.
Old Settler’s already has been widely recognized for its contribution to Central Texas culture; with over 30 bands performing for 16,000 roots-music fans each year, it’s considered among the major events that help the region sustain its status as the “live music capital of the world.” And now, as it plants roots of its own on its new 45-acre property, Old Settler’s cements its status as the sole roots music and camping festival in the Central Texas area.

'''12 April 1999, Old Settler’s Park, Round Rock, Texas:''' Karen Abrahams, Leeann Atherton, Bells of Joy, Cactus Pickers, Guy Clark, Classical Grass, Slaid Cleaves, Cornerstone, John Cowan, Fred Eaglesmith, Joe Ely, Good, Bad & Bluegrass, Patty Griffin, High Standard, Jill Jones & the Lonestar Chorale, Lone Star Bluegrass Band, Moonlighters, Tim O’Brien, Danny Santos & the Sinners, South Austin Gospel Choir, Southern Union, Druha Trava, Two High String Band
'''10 4 & 5 April 1997, Old Settler’s Park, Round Rock, Texas:''' Karen Abrahams, Ana Egge Band, Asylum Street Spankers, The Bad Livers, Russ Barenburg & Edgar Meyer, Blue Highway, Bluegrass Reunion with David Grisman, Sara Elizabeth Campbell, Vassar Clements & Herb Pederson, David Grisman Quartet, Iris Dement, Darcy Deville, Jerry Douglas, Ed Miller Band, Joe Ely, Fairfield Four, Steve Forbert, Grazmatics, Richard Greene & the Grass is Greener, Erik Hokkanen & Friends, Steve James, Alison Krauss & Union Station, Claire Lynch & the Front Porch String Band, Kim Miller, Paul Glasse Band, Toni Price, Peter Rowan, Don Walser, Doc Watson & Jack Lawrence, Tony Williamson & Friends.

page.title: Pre-1975 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons

revision.text:
The years before 1975 featured the '''pre-1975 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons'''. Each season was an ongoing event in the annual cycle of [[tropical cyclone]] formation. The North Indian tropical cyclone season has no bounds, but they tend to form between April and December, peaks in May and November. These dates conventionally delimit the period of each year when most tropical cyclones form in the northern [[Indian Ocean]]. Below are the most significant cyclones in the time period. Because much of the North Indian coastline is near sea level and prone to flooding, these cyclones can easily kill many with storm surge and flooding. These cyclones are among the deadliest on earth in terms of numbers killed.
'''[[List of North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons|North Indian cyclone seasons]]'''
Pre-1980 [[1980-1984 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons|1980–1984]] [[1985-1989 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons|1985–1989]] [[1990 North Indian Ocean cyclone season|1990]] [[1991 North Indian Ocean cyclone season|1991]]
==1700s== ===1721 Madras cyclone=== {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2017}} It was a [[cyclone]] which struck the city of [[Madras]] (now Chennai) in the [[Madras Presidency]] on 13 and 14 November 1721. The cyclone was one of the most severe in the history of the city and destroyed bridges and even suburban villages. The damages were high and three ships of the [[British East India Company]] were lost. The Island Bridge connecting [[Fort St George]] with [[The Island, Chennai|The Island]] was badly damaged as a result of the cyclone. ===1737 Calcutta Cyclone=== On 7 October 1737, a [[natural disaster]] struck the city of [[Kolkata|Calcutta]] (modern-day Kolkata) in [[India]]. For a long time this was believed in [[Europe]] to have been the result of an [[earthquake]], but it is now believed to have been a [[tropical cyclone]].{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/world/most_destructive.php |title=Earthquakes with 50,000 or More Deaths |date=March 29, 2010 |publisher=USGS |accessdate=6 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091102112417/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/world/most_destructive.php |archivedate=November 2, 2009 }}[http://cires.colorado.edu/~bilham/gif_images/1737Calcutta.pdf] Bilham, The 1737 Calcutta Earthquake and Cyclone Evaluated, Bull. Seism. Soc. Amer. 84(5), 1650–1657, 1994. [[Thomas Joshua Moore]], the duties collector for the [[British East India Company]] in Calcutta, wrote in his official report that a storm and flood had destroyed nearly all the thatched buildings and killed 3,000 of the city's inhabitants. Other reports from merchant ships indicated an earthquake and [[tidal surge]] were to blame, destroying 20,000 ships in the harbor and killing 300,000 people. It should be noted that the population of Calcutta at the time was around 3,000–20,000. Although there seems to be little evidence for the popular figure of 300,000 deaths[http://cires.colorado.edu/~bilham/1737Earthquake.html colorado.edu, ''Background to the 1737 "event" ''] or for the existence of an earthquake at all, it is this number that shows up in popular literature.[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Quake+sleuth+%27saves%27+300%2c000+lives.+%28seismologist+Roger+Bilham...-a015187013 ''Quake sleuth 'saves' 300,000 lives.''] At the same time, the figure of 3,000 is only an estimation of the number of deaths inside the city itself.[http://www.imdmumbai.gov.in/cycdisasters.htm Cyclone Related Disasters] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051025071035/http://www.imdmumbai.gov.in/cycdisasters.htm |date=October 25, 2005 }} This apparent incongruity in the data suggests a possible mix-up with the numbers for the 1839 Coringa cyclone mentioned in this article, which also suggest 20,000 sunk ships and 300,000 fatalities. Both of these figures may stem from the 300,000 figure in the 1737 super cyclone in the West Bengal region, as neither one has similar numbers, according to the [https://web.archive.org/web/20100605095539/http://ncrmp.gov.in/ncrmp/AnnIIb.html National Cyclone Risk Mitigation Project's site]. ===December 1789 Indian Cyclone=== Strong [[storm surge]] from a cyclone that hit [[Coringa, India]] destroyed the port and killed 20,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.emergency-management.net/cyclone.htm|title=Cyclone|date=2003-07-02|accessdate=2010-04-15|author=Emergency Disaster Management, Inc.}} ==Early 1800s== ===1831 Odisha cyclone=== An intense cyclone struck Odisha.{{cite journal|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/p3v1780383k467t7/|title=Mitigation of Flooding and Cyclone Hazard in Orissa, India |author1=P. Chittibabu |author2=S. K. Dube |author3=J. B. Macnabb |author4=T. S. Murty |author5=A. D. Rao |author6=U. C. Mohanty |author7=P. C. Sinha |date=February 2004|accessdate=2010-04-15|doi=10.1023/B:NHAZ.0000023362.26409.22|pages=455–485|journal=Natural Hazards|volume=31|number=2|ISSN=0921-030X }} ===1833 West Bengal cyclone=== A ship reported a pressure of 891 mbar (26.30 inHg) at [[Khejuri II#Khijri|Kedgeree]], India.https://books.google.com/books?id=8kXwskQHBLoC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=madagascar+1899+pressure&source=bl&ots=qEKb-I571S&sig=zQUujxd2_ejSJSV4stzbBIi6x2g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiRnvGkjKjOAhXj5oMKHX28B_MQ6AEIJDAD#v=onepage&q=madagascar%201899%20pressure&f=false ===November 1839 Coringa cyclone=== {{for|a similar cyclone in terms of storm surge and (possibly) size|Cyclone Mahina}} On 25 November 1839, an enormous cyclone caused a 40-foot storm surge that hit [[Coringa, Andhra Pradesh]], wiped out the harbor city, destroyed vessels in its bay, and killed 300,000 people. Survivors never entirely rebuilt the city. ===Bengal cyclone of October 1847=== This intense cyclone moved into Bengal state. A total of 75,000 people and 6000 cattle perished during the storm.{{cite web|title=DISASTER VULNERABILITY OF COASTAL STATES: A Short Case Study of Orissa, India|ssrn=1074845|page=4|author1=Dipankar C. Patnaik |author2=N. Sivagnanam |lastauthoramp=yes |date=November 2007|accessdate=2010-04-15|publisher=Social Science Research Network}} ==Late 1800s== ===1864 Calcutta Cyclone=== [[File:1864 Calcutta Cyclone.JPG|thumb|The 1864 Calcutta Cyclone]] On October 5, a powerful cyclone hit near Calcutta, India, killing around 60,000 people.{{cite book |title=Report On The Calcutta Cyclone Of The 5th October 1864 |last=Gastrell |first=J. E. |authorlink= |author2=Henry F. Blanford |year=1866 |publisher=Government Of Bengal |location=Calcutta |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3khBrTZHDM8C |accessdate=2009-08-15}} The anemometer in the city was blown away during the cyclone. Over 100 brick homes and tens of thousands of tiled and straw huts were leveled. Most ships in the harbor (172 out of 195) were either damaged or destroyed.{{cite web|url=http://www.1902encyclopedia.com/C/CAL/calcutta.html|title=Calcutta|publisher=1902 Encyclopedia|year=2010|accessdate=2010-04-15}} The cyclone of 1864 destroyed the ports at [[Khejuri II (community development block)#Khejuri port|Khejuri]] and [[Hijli Kingdom|Hijli]].{{cite web | url = http://www.contai.info/cyclone1.php | title = Cyclones and floods at Contai (page 4) | work = | accessdate = 2011-08-02 | publisher = contai.info | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111003011159/http://www.contai.info/cyclone1.php | archivedate = 2011-10-03 | df = }} ===November 1867 Great Calcutta cyclone=== The anemometer in the city was blown away during the cyclone. A lack of storm surge minimized the overall damage from this system. ===October 1874 Bengal cyclone=== This severe cyclone killed 80,000 people and caused significant damage. ===October 1876 Backergunge cyclone=== {{main article|Great Backerganj Cyclone of 1876}} On October 31, a cyclone hit the [[Meghna River|Meghna River Delta]] area of India. The storm surge killed 100,000, and the disease after the storm killed another 100,000. ===June 1885 Aden cyclone=== A cyclone had formed near the [[Laccadive Islands]] on May 24, {{convert|555|km|mi}} west of southern India. The SS Mergui encountered the cyclone off the Horn of Africa, {{convert|400|km|mi}} east of [[Socotra]] on June 1 and reported it stronger than the tropical cyclone which struck Calcutta in 1864. Just before midnight on the night of June 1, the Diomed reported winds of hurricane force and a pressure of {{convert|984|mb|inHg}}. The ship Peshawar reported a westerly hurricane at the east end of the Gulf of Aden towards midnight on the night of June 2. At noon on June 3, the Tantallon reported a pressure of {{convert|943|mb|inHg}} near 12.5N 45.5E. On June 3, the German [[corvette]] Augusta, the French dispatch boat Renard, and the British ship SS Speke Hall were lost in the storm in the [[Gulf of Aden]]. The system continued westward and shrank in scale as it moved into the entrance of the [[Red Sea]], crossing the coast of [[Djibouti]].{{cite journal|journal=Weather|volume=57|pages=247–255|date=July 2002|title=Monsoon Tropical Cyclones: Part 2|author=David Membery|number=7|publisher=[[Royal Meteorological Society]]|doi=10.1256/004316502760195911|bibcode = 2002Wthr...57..246M }} ===1885 Odisha cyclone=== An intense cyclone struck Odisha. it killed one person. ===June 1890 Muscat cyclone=== This system formed off the west coast of India during the first week of June and moved northwest towards the [[Arabian peninsula]]. Approaching the [[Gulf of Oman]], strong winds and heavy rains affected Sur during the afternoon on June 4. Rain spread west that evening towards Muscat, where winds increased to hurricane-force from the north-northeast early on June 5. The eye of the storm made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] at Sohar at dusk on June 5, eventually dissipating well inland. Heavy rains fell at the hospital in Muscat, where {{convert|11.24|in|mm}} were recorded. This led to flooding which took several hundred lives. Several thousand date trees were uprooted by the storm's winds and carried away by its floods. Several homes were leveled in Muscat and Mutrah. Fifty perished from downing near the coast or being buried by debris. Overall, 727 people lost their lives. ===1895 Odisha cyclone=== An intense cyclone struck Odisha. ===1895 Balochistan cyclone=== In 1895, a cyclonic storm hit the [[Makran]] coast in [[Balochistan]] province in modern-day Pakistan.[http://indianweatherman.blogspot.com/2010/06/cyclone-history-for-karachi.html Indian Weather Man (IWM): Cyclone History for Karachi] ==Early 1900s== ===May 1902 Karachi cyclone=== In May 1902, a cyclonic storm struck the coast in the vicinity of [[Karachi]]. ===June 1907 Karachi cyclone=== In June 1907, a tropical storm struck the coast near Karachi.http://indianweatherman.blogspot.com/2010/06/cyclone-history-for-[[karachi]].html ===October 1942 Bengal cyclone=== On October 16, a cyclone hit near the [[India]]/[[Bangladesh]] border, resulting in around 40,000 fatalities. A wind gust of 225 km/h (140 mph) was recorded. ===July 1944 Karachi cyclone=== On 27 July 1944, a cyclone left some 20,000 people homeless in Karachi.{{cite web|url=http://www.ndma.gov.pk/Publications/livingwithdisasters.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709085830/http://www.ndma.gov.pk/Publications/livingwithdisasters.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-09 |df= }} ===November 1946 Andhra coast cyclone=== This significant storm killed 750 people and led to a loss of 30,000 cattle. ===1948 Balochistan cyclone=== In 1948, a tropical storm made landfall along the [[Makran]] coast in [[Balochistan]] province in [[Pakistan]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.wxp.unisys.com/hurricane/n_indian/1948/index.html |title=Unisys Weather: 1948 Hurricane/Tropical Data for Northern Indian Ocean |access-date=2010-12-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717163226/http://www.wxp.unisys.com/hurricane/n_indian/1948/index.html |archive-date=2011-07-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==1950s== ===Tropical Depression Vae=== [[Typhoon Vae]] crossed over into the Indian Ocean in 1952. ===June 1956 India cyclone=== This cyclone brought torrential rainfall to [[Midnapore district]] in West Bengal. About 20,000 people were left homeless, while another 20,000 people were left stranded near the [[Assam]] border after the [[Haora River]] topped its banks. There was an estimated 480 fatalities, most caused by [[landslide]]s. ===December 1957 cyclone=== A cyclone developed over the Arabian Sea near the [[Gulf of Oman]] on December 27. Moving westward, the storm lashed [[Bahrain]] with winds of {{convert|110|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. An offshore oil rig collapsed, killing 20 [[Royal Dutch Shell]] employees.{{cite book|author=David Longshore|title=Encyclopedia of Hurricanes, Typhoons, and Cyclones|publisher=[[Infobase Publishing]]|date=May 12, 2010|pages=113, 258|isbn=1438118791|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8kXwskQHBLoC&dq=david+longshore+hurricanes+typhoons&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=February 26, 2016}} ===February 1959 cyclone=== A cyclone originating over the Arabian Sea left 500 fatalities in Bahrain. ===May 1959 Salalah cyclone=== This system first became a [[low-pressure area]] near the Laccadive Islands on May 19, tracking northwest towards the Arabian peninsula. The system made landfall at Raysut on May 24. At Salalah, skies clouded over on May 23 as the pressure fell significantly. Winds turned northerly before midnight that night. At 1 a.m. on May 24 the peak of the storm's winds arrived. [[Maximum sustained wind]]s were estimated at {{convert|70|kn|km/h}} and the pressure at Salalaha fell to {{convert|968|mb|inHg}}. Many vessels offshore, including two large passenger ships, went to pieces. Five buildings collapsed and several roofs were blown away by the cyclone. Salalah recorded {{convert|82|mm|in}} of rain at their airport. A total of 141 lives from the ship Samha were taken during this tempest. ==1960s== ===1960=== [[File:1960 North Indian Ocean cyclone season summary map.png|thumb|right|Track map of all storms during the 1960 season]] {{Main article|1960 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} Fifteen depressions developed during the course of the 1960 season, with five becoming cyclonic storms. The majority of activity took place in the Bay of Bengal, with eleven cyclones forming there. The season's first storm formed over the Arabian Sea on May 10. Though it remained over water for its entire existence, several vessels encountered the storm and reported hurricane-force winds as well as a pressure of 974 mbar (hPa; 28.77 inHg). The deadliest and most intense cyclone of the season was Severe Cyclonic Storm Ten, which killed 14,174 in East Pakistan in early November. Attaining peak winds estimated at 150 km/h (90 mph) and a pressure of 966.7 mbar (hPa; 28.55 inHg), it struck just three weeks after the previous system devastated the same area. Producing a 6.1 m (20 ft) storm tide that swept 16 km (10 mi) inland, several coastal islands were completely submerged. An estimated 200,000–300,000 were left homeless in the wake of the two storms. These systems marked the start of an unusually active period of cyclones impacting East Pakistan, culminating ten years later with the 1970 Bhola cyclone that killed 300,000–500,000 people. During the course of the season, several depressions impacted India, each producing heavy rain. Collectively, these systems killed 125 people. {{clear}} ===1961=== [[File:1961 North Indian Ocean cyclone season summary map.png|thumb|right|Track map of all storms during the 1961 season]] {{Main article|1961 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} {{clear}} ===1962=== [[File:1962 North Indian Ocean cyclone season summary map.png|thumb|right|Track map of all storms during the 1962 season]] {{Main article|1962 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} {{clear}} ===1963=== [[File:1963 North Indian Ocean cyclone season summary map.png|thumb|right|Track map of all storms during the 1963 season]] {{Main article|1963 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} ;May Salalah cyclone On May 19, a tropical disturbance formed over the Laccadive Islands, before tracking northwest towards the Arabian peninsula. The system achieved cyclone intensity on May 22. A [[United States Weather Bureau]] research flight flew into the {{convert|12|nmi|km}}-wide eye of the hurricane-strength system, and found a central pressure of {{convert|947|mb|inHg}}. A ship {{convert|111|km|mi}} west of the system reported winds of {{convert|68|kn|km/h}}. At Salalah, a strong northerly wind set in during the morning of May 25. Later in the day, winds increased to [[gale]] force and a [[dust storm|sandstorm]] reduced visibility to {{convert|400|m|ft}}. Later in the day of May 26 winds again increased to [[gale]] force and another sandstorm reduced visibility to {{convert|500|m|ft}}. As winds increased to {{convert|60|kn|km/h}} the sandstorm became more severe, with visibility restricted to {{convert|50|m|ft}}. Late on the night of the 26th, winds shifted to northeast and heavy rains fell across the region through the morning hours. Skies remained cloudy with periods of rain into May 28. A total of {{convert|230|mm|in}} was recorded at Salalah. ;May East Pakistan II cyclone On May 28, a cyclone hit present-day Bangladesh (then known as East Pakistan province), causing 22,000 fatalities due to storm surge and flooding.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-05-28/news/mn-16292_1_20th-century-natural-disasters|title=20th-Century Natural Disasters|date=1985-05-28|accessdate=2010-04-15|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} {{clear}} ===1964=== [[File:1964 North Indian Ocean cyclone season summary map.png|thumb|right|Track map of all storms during the 1964 season]] {{Main article|1964 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} ===Indus valley cyclone=== It made landfall in [[Tharparkar]] and Hyderabad district in [[Sindh]] province in Pakistan on 12 June.{{Cite web |url=http://www.wxp.unisys.com/hurricane/n_indian/1964/index.html |title=Unisys Weather: 1964 Hurricane/Tropical Data for Northern Indian Ocean |access-date=2010-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717163215/http://www.wxp.unisys.com/hurricane/n_indian/1964/index.html |archive-date=2011-07-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }} However it caused a great loss of life and property in the province. It killed 450 people and left some 400,000 people homeless. ===Ceylon cyclone=== {{Main article|1964 Dhanushkodi cyclone}} {{clear}} ===1965 Bengal Cyclones=== [[File:BayOfBengalTCDec141965.jpg|thumb|This deadly tropical cyclone's picture was taken by the TIROS X weather satellite over the Bay of Bengal on December 14, 1965]] Two cyclones that hit on May 11 and June 1 killed a total of 47,000 people. ===December 1965 East Pakistan cyclone=== A cyclone hit [[East Pakistan]] on December 15, causing about 10,000 casualties.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ifhRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_nMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3800,3927029&dq=pakistan&hl=en St. Petersburg Times – Google News Archive Search] {{clear}} ===November 1966 Madras cyclone=== [[File:Nov319660819zESSA3MadrasCyclone.jpg|thumb|This ESSA 3 satellite image was taken on November 3, 1966 at 0819 UTC of a tropical cyclone striking Madras, India]] A cyclone struck Madras, India on November 3, killing over 50 people and leaving 800,000 people homeless.{{cite journal|journal=Mariners Weather Log|date=March 1967|page=52|title=On the Editor's Desk|volume=11|number=2|publisher=Environmental Science Services Administrarion}} {{clear}} ===October 1967 Odisha cyclone=== On October 12, an intense cyclone struck the state of Odisha and left complete devastation along its path. ===1968 Myanmar cyclone=== On May 10, a cyclone struck Myanmar (then known as Burma), killing 1,037 people and leaving 297,768 people homeless.http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/pnady561.pdf ===1969=== Storms in May and November struck Andhra Pradesh, killing 858 people.{{cite report|date=1997-04-11|title=Technical Annex on a Proposed Loan and Credit to India for an Andhra Pradesh Hazard Mitigation and Emergency Cyclone Recovery Project|page=Attachment 16|url=http://www-wds.worldbank.org/servlet/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/1997/04/11/000009265_3970818103327/Rendered/PDF/multi_page.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=World Bank}} ==1970== ===1970 Bhola cyclone=== {{See also|1970 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} {{Main article|1970 Bhola cyclone}} {{storm path|1970 Bhola cyclone track.png|right}} The [[1970 Bhola cyclone]] was a devastating [[tropical cyclone]] that struck [[East Pakistan]] (now [[Bangladesh]]) and [[India]]'s [[West Bengal]] on November 12, 1970. It was the deadliest tropical cyclone ever recorded, and one of the deadliest [[natural disaster]]s in modern times."[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60F16F7355F11738DDDAB0A94D9415B808BF1D3&scp=2&sq=east%20pakistaon%20cyclone%20deaths&st=cse Disaster; East Pakistan: Cyclone May Be The Worst Catastrophe of Century] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111185714/http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60F16F7355F11738DDDAB0A94D9415B808BF1D3&scp=2&sq=east%20pakistaon%20cyclone%20deaths&st=cse |date=2013-11-11 }}" (pay article), ''The New York Times'', November 22, 1970, p. 169. Up to 500,000 people lost their lives in the storm, primarily as a result of the [[storm surge]] that flooded much of the low-lying islands of the [[Ganges Delta]]. This cyclone was the sixth cyclonic storm of the [[1970 North Indian Ocean cyclone season]], and also the season's strongest, reaching a strength equivalent to a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 3 hurricane]]. The cyclone formed over the central [[Bay of Bengal]] on November 8 and travelled north, intensifying as it did so. It reached its peak with winds of 185 km/h (115 mph) on November 12, and made landfall on the coast of East Pakistan that night. The storm surge devastated many of the offshore islands, wiping out villages and destroying crops throughout the region. In the most severely affected [[Upazilas of Bangladesh|Thana]], [[Tazumuddin Upazila|Tazumuddin]], over 45% of the population of 167,000 was killed by the storm. The [[Pakistan]]i government was severely criticized for its handling of the relief operations following the storm, both by local political leaders in East Pakistan and in the international media. The opposition [[Awami League]] gained a [[landslide victory]] in the province, and continuing unrest between East Pakistan and the central government triggered the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]], which concluded with the creation of the country of Bangladesh. {{Clear}} ==1971== ===1971 Arabian Ocean Cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image=NIndianTC1971029midDMSP.gif |Track= |Formed=October 27 |Dissipated=October 31 |1-min winds=65 }} A tropical cyclone moved through the Arabian Sea near the end of October. {{clear}} ===1971 Odisha cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image=BayOfBengalTCOct2919710802UTCESSA9.gif |Track=14B 1971 track.png |Formed=October 27 |Dissipated=October 31 |1-min winds=100 }} On October 27 a tropical depression formed in the [[Bay of Bengal]]. It tracked northward, steadily strengthening until reaching a peak of 115 mph winds. The cyclone struck [[Cuttack]], a city in [[Odisha]], [[India]], on October 29, and dissipated 2 days later. The storm surge and flooding from the system caused 10,800 fatalities.{{cite web|url=http://www.preventionweb.net/files/8841_Sigma22009e.pdf|title=Natural catastrophes and man-made disasters in 2008: North America and Asia suffer heavy losses|date=21 January 2009|publisher=Swiss Reinsurance Company Ltd|pages=38|accessdate=23 May 2017}} {{Clear}} ==1972== A cyclone in September 1972 struck Andhra Pradesh, killing 100. ===December 1972 Tamil Nadu cyclone=== [[File:The Earth seen from Apollo 17.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Photograph of the Earth from [[Apollo 17]] on December 7. The 1972 Tamil Nadu cyclone can be seen in the top right portion of the planet.]] This system killed 80 people and 150 cattle. The cyclone is visible on ''[[The Blue Marble]]'' photo taken by [[Apollo 17]]. {{clear}} {{clear}} ==1973== ===May 1973 Arabian cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image=ArabianSeaTSMay271973.png |Track= |Formed=May 27 |Dissipated=May 29 |1-min winds=35 }} This system formed in the Arabian Sea on May 27 and struck the Arabian peninsula on May 28, becoming the tenth system to affect the region since 1891.{{cite journal|journal=Mariners Weather Log|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]|date=November 1973|page=366|volume=17|number=6}} {{clear}} ===June 1973 Arabian cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image= |Track= |Formed=June 6 |Dissipated=June 12 |1-min winds=35 |central pressure=991 }} {{clear}} ===October 1973 Bay of Bengal cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image= |Track= |Formed=October 6 |Dissipated=October 12 |1-min winds=45 |central pressure=996 }} {{clear}} ===Early November Bay of Bengal cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image= |Track= |Formed=November 3 |Dissipated=November 9 |1-min winds=75 |central pressure=982 }} {{clear}} ===Mid November Bay of Bengal cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image= |Track= |Formed=November 14 |Dissipated=November 17 |1-min winds=55 |central pressure=994 }} {{clear}} ===December 1973 Bay of Bengal cyclone=== {{Infobox Hurricane Small |Basin=NIO |Image=BayofBengalHUDec81973.gif |Track= |Formed=December 5 |Dissipated=December 9 |1-min winds=60 |central pressure=990 }} This system formed as a tropical depression in the southern Bay on December 5, strengthening into a tropical storm as it turned north-northwest on December 5, then to hurricane strength on December 6. The cyclone recurved, striking Indian near Calcutta on December 9, though its main impacts were across Bangladesh.{{cite journal|journal=Mariners Weather Log|date=March 1974|page=93|title=Hurricane Alley|author=Richard M. DeAngelis|volume=18|number=2}} {{clear}} ==1974== ===April 1974 Arabian Sea cyclone=== [[File:ArabianTCApril1519740332UTC.png|thumb|This Arabian Sea tropical cyclone image was taken on April 15, 1974 at 0332 UTC]] {{clear}} ===May 1974 Arabian Sea cyclone=== [[File:ArabianTSMay191974.png|thumb|This Arabian Sea tropical cyclone image was taken on May 19, 1974]] {{clear}} ===August 1974 Bay of Bengal cyclone=== [[File:BayOfBengalAugust141974.gif|thumb|This is a weather satellite image of an August 14, 1974 Bay of Bengal tropical cyclone]] {{clear}} ===September 21–24, 1974 Arabian Sea cyclone=== [[File:ArabianSeaTCSep1974.png|thumb|right|This weather satellite image of a tropical cyclone in the Arabian Sea was taken on September 23, 1974]] {{clear}} ===September 26–29, 1974 Bay of Bengal cyclone=== ===November 23–28, 1974 Bay of Bengal cyclone=== [[File:BayofBengalNovember281974.gif|thumb|right|This weather satellite image of a strong Bay of Bengal tropical cyclone was taken on November 28, 1974]] This system developed off the eastern coast of southern India on November 23 and strengthened as it moved to the northeast. The system nearly reached hurricane strength as it made landfall near Chittagong late on November 28. A {{convert|10|ft|m}} storm surge accompanied the system's approach to Bangladesh, which inundated several islands offshore. Less than 100 people perished while thousands were left homeless.{{cite journal|journal=Mariners Weather Log|date=March 1975|pages=88–89|title=Hurricane Alley|author=Dick DeAngelis|volume=19|number=2|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]}} {{clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} *[[Tropical cyclones and tornadoes in Pakistan]] *[[List of North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons]] *[[List of tropical cyclones that affected India]] *[[List of tropical cyclones]] *[[Tropical cyclone]] *[[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale]] *[[List of Pacific typhoon seasons]] *[[List of Atlantic hurricane seasons]] *[[List of Pacific hurricane seasons]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ===General references=== {{Refbegin}} * {{cite encyclopedia |title=Cyclone, Hurricane, White squall, Typhoon. |encyclopedia=The Cyclopaedia of Indian And Of Eastern And Southern Asia: Commercial, Industrial, and Scientific, 3rd Edition |volume=I |pages=866–868 |publisher= Bernard Quaritch |location=London |year=1885 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4NArAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA866 |id= |accessdate=2009-08-15 }} {{Refend}} ==External links== *[http://www.usno.navy.mil/JTWC/annual-tropical-cyclone-reports JTWC Archive] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071102075355/http://www.imd.ernet.in/section/nhac/static/cyclone-history-bb.htm Cyclone related disasters] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060519014813/http://www.disaster-management.net/cyclone.htm Cyclones] {{DEFAULTSORT:Pre-1980 North Indian Ocean Cyclone Seasons}} [[Category:Pre-1980 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons| ]] [[Category:Tropical cyclones in India| Pre-1980]] [[Category:Lists of tropical cyclones|Indian Ocean North]] [[Category:Lists of disasters|India]] [[Category:1971 in Asia]] [[Category:1971 meteorology]] [[Category:1971 natural disasters]] [[Category:1972 in Asia]] [[Category:1972 meteorology]] [[Category:1972 natural disasters]] [[Category:1973 in Asia]] [[Category:1973 meteorology]] [[Category:1973 natural disasters]] [[Category:1974 in Asia]] [[Category:1974 meteorology]] [[Category:1974 natural disasters]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox Newspaper | name = Primorske novice | image = | caption = | type = [[Daily newspaper]] | format = | foundation = {{start date and age|1963}} | ceased publication = | price = | owners = Splošna Plovba Portorož and other companies | political = | publisher = Primorske novice ČZD, d.o.o. | editor = Antiša Korljan | staff = | circulation = 65,000 (2013) | headquarters = [[Koper]], [[Slovenia]] | ISSN = | website = [http://www.primorske.si Official website] }} '''''Primorske novice''''' ({{lang-en|Littoral News}}) is a regional daily newspaper published in [[Koper]], [[Slovenia]].
==History and profile== ''Primorske novice'' was establied in 1963<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Michael Biggins|title=Publishing in Slovenia|journal=Slavic & East European Information Resources|date=2001|volume=1|issue=2-3|doi=10.1300/J167v01n02_01|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1300/J167v01n02_01|accessdate=8 December 2014}}</ref> as result of the merger of weekly paper ''Nova Gorica'' (founded in 1947) with another weekly named ''Slovenski Jadran'' (meaning "The Slovene Adriatic" in English; founded in 1950).<ref name=novisad>{{cite web|author1=Jasna Merklin|author2=Petra Znoj|author3=Urška Zalar|title=Reporting about Neighbors in Slovenian Daily Newspapers|url=http://odsek.medijskestudije.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/Mostovi-medijskog-obrazovanja-2011.pdf#page=57|publisher=University of Novi Sad|accessdate=8 December 2014|format=Conference paper|date=July 2011}}</ref> It started as a weekly newspaper<ref name=novisad/> and became a daily in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|title=Slovenia Newspapers Magazines Journals and Weeklies|url=http://www.ljubljanasloveniatravel.com/slovenia-newspapers-magazines-journals-and-weeklies.html|publisher=Ljubljana Slovenia Travel|accessdate=6 December 2014}}</ref> It became also the first regional daily newspaper in the country.<ref name=novisad/>
''Primorske novice'' is published by Primorske novice d.o.o. which is based in [[Koper]] and the paper launched its website in 1996.<ref name=novisad/> It has no political affiliation.<ref name=novisad/>
As of 2009 it was still the only regional daily newspaper in Slovenia.<ref name=novisad/> The 2007 circulation of the paper was 23,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Media|url=http://www.ipaslovenija.org/eng/about/09_media.pdf|work=IPA Section Slovenia|accessdate=15 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128160754/http://www.ipaslovenija.org/eng/about/09_media.pdf|archivedate=28 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It became 65,000 in 2013.<ref>[http://www.nrb.info/podatki National Circulation of Printed Press (in Slovene)]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
{{Slovenian Newspapers}} [[Category:1963 establishments in Slovenia]] [[Category:Publications established in 1963]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Slovenia]] [[Category:Slovene-language newspapers]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Koper]]
