{{multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=August 2013}} {{overly detailed|date=August 2013}} {{unreliable sources|date=August 2013}} }} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Tech Field Day | image = | caption = | location = [[Silicon Valley]], [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]], [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]] | years_active = {{age|2009|11|12}} | founded = {{start date|2009|11|12}} | founders = Stephen Foskett | dates = | frequency = 7 per year | next = | genre = [[Information technology]] | budget = | patron = | organized = Gestalt IT Media, LLC | website = [http://TechFieldDay.com TechFieldDay.com] }} '''Tech Field Day''' is an independently organized [[business conference|conference]] series centered on enterprise [[IT infrastructure]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/justinwarren/2015/08/24/the-rise-of-the-small-independent-conference/|title=The Rise Of The Small Independent Conference|author=Justin Warren|date=|work=Forbes}}</ref> Organized by Gestalt IT Media LLC, the Field Day series is intended to bring together product vendors and independent [[blog]]gers,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogstu.wordpress.com/2010/03/31/blogger-communities/|title=Tapping into blogger communities|last=|first=|date=|website=|accessdate=2017-11-30}}</ref> [[freelance writer]]s, speakers, and leaders of online communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thestorageanarchist.typepad.com/weblog/2010/04/2047-the-gestalt-are-coming-the-gestalt-are-coming.html|title=the gestalt are coming, the gestalt are coming!|accessdate=January 2011|publisher=The Storage Anarchist}}</ref> The Field Day event series began in 2009 with a general datacenter event and expanded in 2010 to include an event focused on enterprise [[computer networking|networking]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.douglasgourlay.com/blog/2010/10/on-gestalt-its-netfield-dat/|title=On Gestalt IT’s NetField Day|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101012024445/http://www.douglasgourlay.com/blog/2010/10/on-gestalt-its-netfield-dat/|archive-date=2010-10-12|dead-url=yes|accessdate=2017-11-30}}</ref>
==Notable Introductions==
Every Field Day event includes presentations by hardware and software vendors, but some notable introductions have also occurred at these events: * [[Data Robotics]] introduced their [[Drobo S]] and [[DroboElite]] models at the 2009 Field Day<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storagenerve.com/2009/11/23/drobo-s-and-drobo-elite-introduced-11232009/|title=DROBO S and DROBO Elite – Introduced 11/23/2009|date=January 2011|publisher=StorageNerve}}</ref> as well as the [[Drobo FS]] at the 2010 Boston event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://basraayman.com/2010/04/06/drobo-announces-their-new-drobo-fs/|title=Drobo announces their new Drobo FS|last=|first=|date=|website=|accessdate=2017-11-30}}</ref> * [[Nimble Storage]] used the 2010 Seattle Field Day as their corporate launch event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://itknowledgeexchange.techtarget.com/storage-soup/does-nimble-dedupe/|title=Does Nimble dedupe?|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=IT Knowledge Exchange|accessdate=2017-11-30}}</ref> * [[Actifio]] used Tech Field Day 4 as their corporate launch event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://actifio.com/press/pr/pr-11-10-2010.aspx|title=ACTIFIO TO DISCUSS DYNAMICS OF DATA MANAGEMENT VIRTUALIZATION AT GESTALT IT TECH FIELD DAY 4 IN SAN JOSE|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Actifio Press Release|accessdate=2017-11-30}}</ref> * [[Druva Software]] used Tech Field Day 5 as their American corporate launch event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.druva.com/2011/02/16/why-druva-is-like-a-cow/|title=Why Druva is Like A Newborn Calf|accessdate=February 10, 2012|publisher=Druva Software}}</ref> * [[Zerto]] and [[Embrane]] gave advance previews before their launches at Tech Field Day 6<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techfieldday.com/2011/zerto-offers-tech-field-day-delegates-sneak-peek/|title=Zerto Offers Tech Field Day Delegates a Sneak Peek|accessdate=February 10, 2012|publisher=Tech Field Day}}</ref> and Networking Field Day 2,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etherealmind.com/scaling-virtual-appliances-embrane/|title=Scaling Virtual Appliances With Embrane|accessdate=February 10, 2012|publisher=EtherealMind}}</ref> respectively. * [[Exablox]] used Storage Field Day 3 as their launch event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/smbit/new-startup-exablox-announced-at-storage-field-day-3/1144|title=New startup Exablox announced at Storage Field Day 3|accessdate=June 3, 2013|publisher=Tech Republic}}</ref> Also at that event, [[Fusion-io]] announced their acquisition of [[NexGen Storage]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siliconslopes.com/beta/?p=142|title=Fusion-io, NexGen CEOs talk acquisition, integration|accessdate=June 3, 2013|publisher=Silicon Slopes|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014184035/http://siliconslopes.com/beta/?p=142|archivedate=October 14, 2013|df=}}</ref> and [[Cisco Systems]] first showed the next-generation MDS Fibre Channel platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wahlnetwork.com/2013/05/06/building-a-monster-san-with-the-cisco-mds-9710-director/|title=Building a Monster SAN with the Cisco MDS 9710 Director|accessdate=June 3, 2013|publisher=Wahl Network}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://techfieldday.com Tech Field Day homepage]
[[Category:Computer conferences]]

{{Infobox Musical |name= The Boy from Oz |image= The Boy from Oz Original Broadway Poster.jpg |caption=Original Broadway poster |music=[[Peter Allen (musician)|Peter Allen]] |lyrics=[[Peter Allen (musician)|Peter Allen]] |book=[[Nick Enright]] (original)
Martin Sherman |basis= |productions= 1998 Sydney
2003 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]
2006 Australian arena tour
2013 Lima, Perú
2018 Melbourne |awards= }} '''''The Boy from Oz''''' is a [[jukebox musical]] based on the life of singer and songwriter [[Peter Allen (musician)|Peter Allen]], featuring songs written by him. The original book is by [[Nick Enright]], with a revised book by Martin Sherman. Premiering in Australia in 1998 starring [[Todd McKenney]], the musical opened in a revised version on Broadway in 2003 with [[Hugh Jackman]] in the title role. ==Plot== === Act I === The musical begins with Australian performer Peter Allen recalling his life story, coming to terms with who he was ("The Lives of Me"). Afterwards, we go back to Allen's childhood in Tenterfield, Australia, where a young boy named Peter Woolnough is performing in local bars for money ("When I Get My Name in Lights"). Peter grows up and joins with Chris Bell to become the Allen Brothers, and they perform in Australian Bandstand ("Love Crazy"). After great success in Australia, the Allen Brothers perform in a Hong Kong Hilton hotel to Chinese businessmen. One evening, another person is watching them from the bar: the legendary Judy Garland. Peter convinces Judy to perform with them ("All I Wanted Was the Dream"), and Judy takes Peter to be the opening act in her concert in New York ("Only an Older Woman"). While in New York, Peter is introduced to Judy's daughter, [[Liza Minnelli|Liza]], and they fall in love ("Best That You Can Do"). There are rumors of Peter's homosexuality, and Judy warns Liza of this ("Don't Wish Too Hard"). Liza gives no attention to her warning and marries Peter ("Come Save Me"). Peter makes some mistakes, and at one of his all night parties Liza walks in on him ("Continental American"), further fueling her suspicions that he is gay. Liza is working hard to get her career going ("She Loves to Hear the Music"), in contrast to Peter's excessive lifestyle. Judy dies, and Peter honors her ("Quiet Please, There's a Lady on Stage"). Liza's world comes crashing down as a result of her mother's death. Liza confronts Peter on his alleged homosexuality, and their marriage ends ("I'd Rather Leave While I'm in Love"). Peter returns to Australia but realizes that he is not who people thought he was ("Not the Boy Next Door"). === Act II === Back in the US, Peter has gone solo and comes to terms with his bisexuality ("Bi-Coastal"). He meets the hardworking fashion model Gregory Connell. Greg does not want to be a part of Peter's life in show business, but he falls in love with Peter ("If You Were Wondering"). They soon get discovered by music producer [[Dee Anthony]], and he gets them a gig at the [[Copacabana (nightclub)|Copacabana]] in New York ("Sure Thing Baby"). Peter's career takes off, and he wins an Oscar for [[Arthur's Theme]], in addition to recording songs that were covered by artists [[Olivia Newton-John]] and [[Frank Sinatra]]. Peter gives his best performance in the [[Radio City Music Hall]] with [[The Rockettes]] ("Everything Old is New Again"), and is surprised to know his mother is also in love. Greg becomes stricken with [[AIDS]], and even though Peter tries to help him carry on, he succumbs to his illness ("Love Don't Need a Reason"). Peter also becomes sick with AIDS, but Greg's spirit urges him to carry on ("I Honestly Love You"). Liza offers her support to Peter, and they both realize they had successful lives and careers without each other ("You and Me"). Peter returns to Australia for a triumphant performance ("I Still Call Australia Home") and tries to tell his mother about his illness, but he can't find a way to tell her ("Don't Cry Out Loud"). Peter succumbs to his disease, and he reflects on his life realizing he has no regrets as he passes away ("Once Before I Go"), but not before going out in style with a farewell performance ("I Go to Rio").{{cite web |url=http://www.theatre-musical.com/boyfromoz/synopsis.html |title=The Boy from Oz: Synopsis |website=Stacy's Musical Village |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415060054/http://www.theatre-musical.com/boyfromoz/synopsis.html |archivedate=April 15, 2012 |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} ==Production history== ===Original Australian production=== ''The Boy from Oz'' had its world premiere, directed by [[Gale Edwards]], at [[Her Majesty's Theatre, Sydney]], Australia, on 5 March 1998 and toured Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth, playing to over 1.2 million theatre patrons. It ran for a total 766 performances over two years.{{cite web |url=http://www.audiomastermind.com/detail-the_boy_from_oz-14567.html |title=The Boy From Oz... in Oz |website=Audiomastermind.com |accessdate=November 13, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726041520/http://www.audiomastermind.com/detail-the_boy_from_oz-14567.html |archivedate=July 26, 2012}} The production starred showman [[Todd McKenney]] as Peter Allen and [[Divinyls]] frontwoman [[Chrissy Amphlett]] as [[Judy Garland]], Angela Toohey as Liza Minnelli and introduced [[Mathew Waters]] as Young Peter Allen. ===Broadway=== ''The Boy from Oz'' began previews on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Imperial Theatre (Broadway)|Imperial Theatre]] on 16 September 2003 and opened on 16 October 2003. It closed on 12 September 2004, at the end of [[Hugh Jackman]]'s contract. It was adapted for the American audience by playwright [[Martin Sherman]], who removed some of the Australian terms (such as "jackaroo") and expanded the role of U.S. characters Garland and Minnelli. The musical played 32 previews and 365 performances. Directed by Philip William McKinley, with choreography by Joey McKneely, it starred Jackman as Peter Allen, [[Isabel Keating]] as [[Judy Garland]], [[Stephanie J. Block]] as [[Liza Minnelli]], [[Beth Fowler]] as Marion Woolnough, [[Jarrod Emick]] as Peter's lover Greg Connell, and [[John Hill (actor)|John Hill]] as [[Mark Herron]] (Judy's husband). Jackman won the 2004 [[Tony Award]] for Best Leading Actor in a Musical and the [[Drama Desk Award]] for Outstanding Actor in a Musical, and Keating won the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical. The show also received nominations for four other Tony Awards, including Best Musical.{{cite web |url=http://www.ibdb.com/production.asp?ID=13424 |title=The Boy from Oz |website=[[Internet Broadway Database]] |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} [[Ben Brantley]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' panned the show, calling it an "indisputably bogus show", but praised Jackman's performance.{{cite news |last=Brantley |first=Ben |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/17/movies/theater-review-flash-of-70-s-sequins.html |title=Theater Review; Flash Of 70's Sequins |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 17, 2003 |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} The musical recouped its investment of $8.25 million.{{cite news |last=Green |first=Jesse |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/05/theater/newsandfeatures/05GREE.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all&position= |title=Theater: Debriefing; Eight Days a Week |newspaper=The New York Times |date=September 5, 2004 |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} ===Australian arena tour=== ''The Boy from Oz'' returned to Australia from 3 August 2006 to 10 September 2006 in a new production especially designed for the arena stage (audiences of over 10,000 people), called ''Boy from Oz Arena Spectacular''. Directed by [[Kenny Ortega]], [[Hugh Jackman]] reprised his New York role as Peter Allen. He was joined by Australian actresses [[Chrissy Amphlett]] and Angela Toohey, reprising their roles as [[Judy Garland]] and [[Liza Minnelli]]. [[Shardyn Fahey-Leigh]] played the role of Young Peter Allen with Dylan Speedy. Rarmian Newton and Joshua Waiss Gates, both of whom later starred in ''[[Billy Elliot the Musical]]'', were understudies in the Australian production. Peter's mother, Marion, was played by [[Colleen Hewett]].{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/brisbane/stories/s1732659.htm |title=The Boy From Oz |date=September 4, 2006 |website=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=November 13, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080306021851/http://www.abc.net.au/brisbane/stories/s1732659.htm |archivedate=March 6, 2008}}{{cite magazine |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117931239.html?categoryid=33&cs=1 |first=David |last=Rooney |title=Abroad: The Boy from Oz |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=August 6, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091201181156/http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117931239.html?categoryid=33&cs=1 |archivedate=December 1, 2009 |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} The show had a support cast of 40 singer-dancers and a 25-piece orchestra.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/97912.html |first=Ernio |last=Hernandez |title=Hugh Jackman The Boy From Oz Tour Gets New Director, Cast and Dates for Oz Return |magazine=[[Playbill]] |date=February 13, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060626023852/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/97912.html |archivedate=June 26, 2006 |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} The show also featured the vocals of Australian girls' high school choirs from [[Penrhos College, Perth|Penrhos College]]{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} when in Perth, and, while in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Brisbane, it featured the vocals of 100 girls from the [[Australian Girls Choir]]. ===Melbourne revival=== To celebrate ''The Boy from Oz'' turning 20, [[The Production Company]] will stage a new production as a part of their 2018 season. [[Rohan Browne]] stars as Peter Allen, and [[Caroline O'Connor (actress)|Caroline O’Connor]] returns to The Production Company for the role of Judy Garland. Matthew Manahan will play Greg Connell. ===International productions=== In [[Peru]], the musical was released in May 2013, starring [[Marco Zunino]] as Allen,{{cite news |url=http://archivo.elcomercio.pe/luces/arte/musical-broadwaythe-boy-from-oz-adaptado-lima-noticia-1348968 |title=Musical de Broadway "The Boy From Oz" será adaptado en Lima |newspaper=[[El Comercio (Peru)|El Comercio]] |date=December 17, 2011 |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} Érika Villalobos appeared as Liza Minnelli and Elena Romero as Judy Garland. It was the first Spanish language adaptation of this musical.{{cite web |url=http://entretenimiento.terra.com.pe/marco-zunino-recibe-consejos-de-actor-hugh-jackman,423ce2a7be705310VgnVCM3000009af154d0RCRD.html |title=Marco Zunino recibe consejos de actor Hugh Jackman |website=entretenimiento.terra.com.pe}}{{dead link|date=November 2017}} ==Song list (Broadway version)== ''All songs written by Peter Allen except as noted'' {{Col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Act 1 * The Lives of Me - ''Peter Allen'' * When I Get My Name in Lights - ''Boy and Ensemble'' * When I Get My Name in Lights (Reprise) - ''Peter'' * Love Crazy - ''Chris Bell, Peter and Ensemble'' (Allen & Adrienne Anderson) * [[Waltzing Matilda]] - ''Peter and Chris'' (in Mandarin) * All I Wanted Was the Dream - ''[[Judy Garland]]'' * Only an Older Woman - ''Judy, Peter, Chris and Mark Herron'' * [[Arthur's Theme (Best That You Can Do)|Best That You Can Do]] - ''Peter and [[Liza Minnelli]]'' (by [[Burt Bacharach]], [[Carole Bayer Sager]], Allen & [[Christopher Cross]]) * Don't Wish Too Hard - ''Judy'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * Come Save Me - ''Liza and Peter'' * Continental American - ''Peter and Ensemble'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * She Loves to Hear the Music - ''Liza and Ensemble'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * Quiet Please, There's a Lady On Stage - ''Peter and Judy'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * I'd Rather Leave While I'm in Love - ''Liza and Peter'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * Not the Boy Next Door - ''Peter and Marion Woolnough'' (music by Allen, lyrics by [[Dean Pitchford]]) {{col-break}} ;Act 2 * Bi-Coastal - ''Peter and Trio'' (written by Allen, [[David Foster]] & [[Tom Keane]]) * If You Were Wondering - ''Peter and Greg Connell'' * Sure Thing Baby - ''Dee Anthony, Greg, Peter, Trio and Male Ensemble'' * Everything Old is New Again - ''Peter and The Rockettes'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * Everything Old is New Again (Reprise) - ''Marion, Dee and Greg'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * Love Don't Need a Reason [https://web.archive.org/web/20110714011115/http://www.lyricszoo.com/peter-allen-hugh-jackman/love-dont-need-a-reason-hugh-jackman/] - ''Peter and Greg'' (by Allen, [[Michael Callen]] & Marsha Malamet) * [[I Honestly Love You]] - ''Greg'' (by Allen & [[Jeff Barry]]) * You and Me - ''Liza and Peter'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * [[I Still Call Australia Home]] - ''Peter and Ensemble'' * [[Don't Cry Out Loud (song)|Don't Cry Out Loud]] - ''Marion'' (music by Allen, lyrics by Sager) * Once Before I Go - ''Peter'' * [[I Go to Rio]] - ''Peter and Company'' (by Allen & Anderson) {{col-end}} ;Original Australian Cast Album track list: # Continental American # When I Get My Name In Lights # Pretty Keen Teen # All I Wanted Was the Dream # Only an Older Woman # Don't Wish Too Hard # Sure Thing Baby # Quiet Please, There's a Lady on Stage # I'd Rather Leave While I'm In Love # (I've Been) Taught by Experts # Not the Boy Next Door # (When) Everything Old is New Again # (Arthur's Theme) Best That You Can Do # Love Don't Need a Reason # She Loves to Hear the Music # I Honestly Love You # I Still Call Australia Home # Don't Cry Out Loud # Tenterfield Saddler # I Go to Rio # The Lives of Me # Love Crazy # Come Save Me # Bi-Coastal # If You Were Wondering # You and Me # Once Before I Go {{Div col end}} ==Reviews== The Broadway production received favorable reviews. In his review for ''The New York Times'', [[Ben Brantley]] wrote, "His limbs twirling like the blades of a windmill, Mr. Jackman channels the energy that was Allen with a rejuvenating life force all his own. And you don’t feel — as you so often do with such interpretations — that your memories of the prototype have been blurred. This is a performance that, against the odds, holds on to its integrity." [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']], writing about the Australian arena tour, said, "When he first performed the role on Broadway in 2003, Hugh Jackman’s charisma, vitality and breezy confidence onstage far outshone the narrative or emotional scope of the by-the-numbers biomusical of singer-songwriter Peter Allen. The scales have been tipped even further toward the performer in this pumped-up reconfiguration of the show, playing state capitals in venues of 10,000 seats or more. It’s as much a concert platform for a returning local boy made good in Hollywood as it is a life story of Peter Allen. And that’s no bad thing."{{cite magazine |url=https://variety.com/2006/legit/reviews/the-boy-from-oz-1200514370/ |title=The Boy from Oz |first=David |last=Rooney |date=6 August 2006 |magazine=Variety |accessdate=November 13, 2017}} ==Awards and nominations== ===Original Australian production=== {| class="wikitable" width="95%" |- ! width="5%"| Year ! width="20%"| Award Ceremony ! width="45%"| Category ! width="20%"| Nominee ! width="10%"| Result |- | rowspan="8" align="center"| 2001 | rowspan="8"| [[Helpmann Awards]] | colspan="2"| [[Helpmann Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] | {{won}} |- | [[Helpmann Award for Best New Australian Work|Best New Australian Work]] | [[Nick Enright]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Helpmann Award for Best Direction of a Musical|Best Direction of a Musical]] | [[Gale Edwards]] | {{won}} |- | Best Choreography in a Musical | [[Anthony Van Laast]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Helpmann Award for Best Male Actor in a Musical|Best Male Actor in a Musical]] | [[Todd McKenney]] | {{won}} |- | [[Helpmann Award for Best Female Actor in a Musical|Best Female Actor in a Musical]] | [[Chrissie Amphlett]] | {{nom}} |- | Best Musical Direction | [[Max Lambert]] | {{won}} |- | Best Sound Design | Wyn Milsom | {{nom}} |- |} The original Australian production was also received six Melbourne [[Green Room Awards]] for 1999, including Outstanding Contribution by a Music Theatre Management.{{cite web |title=1999 Music Theatre |url=http://www.greenroom.org.au/1999/99musictheatre.htm |website=Green Room Awards |accessdate=20 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031129183533/http://www.greenroom.org.au/1999/99musictheatre.htm |archivedate=November 29, 2003}} It was also nominated for the Green Room Award for Best New Australian Play.{{cite web |title=1999 Drama |url=http://www.greenroom.org.au/1999/99drama.htm |website=Green Room Awards |accessdate=20 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031126175322/http://www.greenroom.org.au/1999/99drama.htm |archivedate=November 26, 2003}} ===Original Broadway production=== {| class="wikitable" width="95%" Featured Actress in a Musical|Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Musical]] | [[Beth Fowler]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Isabel Keating]] | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="3"| [[Drama Desk Award]] | [[Drama Desk revision.comment: /* United States */ Adding the 1968 televised town hall campaigns by Richard Nixon
revision.text:
{{About|an event where politicians talk with constituents|the form of municipal decision-making|Town meeting}}
{{globalize/US|date=February 2017}}
[[File:West Hartford, Connecticut health care reform town hall meeting, 2009-09-02.jpg|thumb|A town hall meeting in [[West Hartford, Connecticut]]]] '''Town hall meetings''', also referred to as '''town halls''' or '''town hall forums''', are a way for local and national politicians to meet with their constituents, either to hear from them on topics of interest or to discuss specific upcoming legislation or regulation. During periods of active political debate, town halls can be a locus for protest and more active debate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rop.org/halfway-through-rops-reflections-on-town-hall-madness/|title=Halfway through: ROP's Reflections on Town Hall Madness - Rural Organizing Project|date=2009-08-27|newspaper=Rural Organizing Project|access-date=2017-02-18|language=en-US}}</ref>
Despite their name, town hall meetings need not take place in a town hall. They are commonly held in a range of venues, including schools, libraries, municipal buildings, and churches. A number of officials have also experimented with digital formats for town halls. Town hall meetings organized by national politicians are often held in a variety of locations distributed across a voting district so that elected representatives can receive feedback from a larger proportion of constituents.
Historically, no specific rules or guidelines have defined a town hall meeting.<ref name="Real">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2A35hJAR7u0C&dq|title=Real Democracy: The New England Town Meeting and How It Works|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0226077963|last1=Bryan|first1=Frank M.|accessdate=2012-10-25}}</ref> Any event that allows constituent participation with a politician may be called a town hall, including gatherings in person, group phone calls, or events on Internet platforms such as Facebook or Twitter. Attendees use town halls to voice their opinions and question [[elected official]]s, [[political candidate]]s, and public figures.<ref name="Anup">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Exv7fHk5V4C&pg=PT650|title=Presidential Campaigns, Slogans, Issues, and Platforms|last2=Hammond|first2=Scott John|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|others=|year=2012|isbn=9780313380938|edition=2d|series=|volume=|location=|page=|pages=|at=|language=|chapter=|type=|format=|bibcode=|doi=|oclc=|id=|quote=|ref=|author-mask=|last1=Roberts|first1=Robert North|authorlink1=|authorlink2=|editor1-first=|editor1-last=|editor1-link=|trans-title=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|accessdate=|origyear=|trans-chapter=|chapterurl=|laysummary=|laydate=|lastauthoramp=}}</ref><ref name="Williamson">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LOQVCpi8FBMC&pg=PA150&dq=town+hall+political+event&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZZNIUeDFL-mxiQLZqICQDg&ved=0CEEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=town%20hall%20political%20event&f=false|title=How to Run for Political Office and Win|last2=|first2=|publisher=Atlantic Publishing Company|others=|year=2010|isbn=9781601384089|edition=|series=|volume=|location=|page=|pages=150–151|at=|language=|chapter=|type=|format=|bibcode=|doi=|oclc=|id=|quote=|ref=|author-mask=|last1=Williamson|first1=Melanie|authorlink1=|authorlink2=|editor1-first=|editor1-last=|editor1-link=|trans-title=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|accessdate=|origyear=|trans-chapter=|chapterurl=|laysummary=|laydate=|lastauthoramp=}}</ref> In contrast to [[town meetings]], a type of [[Direct democracy|direct democratic]] rule that originated in colonial [[New England]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dorchesteratheneum.org/page.php?id=54|title=Dorchester Atheneum|website=www.dorchesteratheneum.org|access-date=2017-02-18}}</ref> attendees do not [[vote]] on issues during town hall meetings.
In the [[United States]], town halls are a common way for national politicians to connect or reconnect with their constituents during recesses, when they are in their home districts away from [[Washington DC|Washington, DC]].
== History == Town hall meetings can be traced back to the [[Colonial history of the United States|colonial era]] of the United States and to the 19th century in Australia.<ref name=":1" /> The introduction of television and other new media technologies in the 20th century led to a fresh flourishing of town hall meetings in the United States as well as experimentation with different formats in the United States and other countries, both of which continue to the present day.
=== United States === Town hall meetings are meant to resemble the New England [[town meeting]] that originated in the 17th century. However, participants in town hall meetings do not actually vote or make legally binding decisions as town meeting voters do.
Some political organizations track publicized town hall events by politicians across the United States.<ref>[https://www.legistorm.com/townhall.html Town Hall Events for national congresspeople, Legistorm]</ref>
The 1858 debates between [[Abraham Lincoln]] and [[Stephen A. Douglas|Stephen Douglas]] in some respects resembled a modern town hall meeting, although the candidates did not take questions from the audience.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/history-town-hall-debate-180960705/|title=The History of the Town Hall Debate|last=Mansky|first=Jackie|newspaper=Smithsonian|access-date=2017-02-18|language=en}}</ref> Not until the twentieth century did presidential candidates commonly campaign in person. Gradually, especially from the 1990s onward, presidential town hall meetings have become nearly as common as [[Stump speech (politics)|stump speeches]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maggs|first=John|year=2004|title=The Format That Saved Clinton|url=|journal=National Journal|volume=|pages=2996|via=}}</ref>
Richard Nixon's 1968 U.S. Presidential campaign staged nine live televised question and answer sessions using a ground-breaking theatre-in-the-round format broadcast with a live studio television audience and local residents directly asking questions of the candidate.<ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theatre_in_the_round#History_of_theatre-in-the-round</ref> The producer of Nixon's "Man in the Arena" <ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yFeWFjbeEQ8</ref> live town-hall programs was Roger Ailes <ref>https://www.nixonfoundation.org/2017/05/roger-ailes-nixons-television-man/</ref>, who later went to on start FOX News <ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Ailes</ref>. Ailes' use of a direct voter-to-candidate question-and-answer format served as the blueprint for subsequent and now ubiquitous town hall candidate formats and even multiple-candidate debates.
Another step in the development of the modern town hall meeting came on March 16, 1977, when [[Jimmy Carter|President Carter]] attended a televised town hall meeting in [[Clinton, Massachusetts]], that was "modeled after" a real town meeting but did not include binding votes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1977/03/16/the-making-of-a-presidential-trip/98647be3-b69a-4b91-a852-5232e2109f02/|title=The Making of a Presidential Trip|last=Walsh|first=Edward|newspaper=Washington Post|access-date=2017-09-03|language=en}}</ref> [[Bill Clinton]] made town hall meetings a part of his presidential campaign.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U44JMDQO8IoC&pg=PA173&dq=%22town+hall+meeting%22+president&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiIpbqE1rzKAhUH2T4KHR-4A00Q6AEIHTAA#v=onepage&q=%22town%20hall%20meeting%22%20president&f=false|title=Politics, Discourse, and American Society: New Agendas|last=Hart|first=Roderick P.|last2=Sparrow|first2=Bartholomew H.|date=2001-01-01|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780742500716|language=en}}</ref>
Interest in town halls fluctuates depending on the level of public interest in the topics being discussed. Controversial or confusing issues that are prominently discussed in the news have led to more town halls being held.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/13/us/politics/affordable-care-act-sensenbrenner-republicans.html|title=Angry Town Hall Meetings on Health Care Law, and Few Answers|last=Kaplan|first=Thomas|date=2017-02-13|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=2017-02-18|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Since the 2000s, town halls held by political candidates have announced and enforced rules on crowd behavior and the scope of questions that may be asked.<ref name="Anup" /><ref name="Williamson" />
; 21st century meetings ;: ''Detailed article: [[List of significant United States town hall meetings]]'' In 2009, [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] groups opposed to the proposed [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|health care reform legislation]] began attending town halls to express their disagreement with the legislation. The large and vocal crowds led some representatives to cancel or scale back their town hall events. Representative [[Brian Baird]] canceled his live town hall meetings after receiving death threats, choosing to hold a telephone conference call with his constituents instead.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|year=|title=The Tea Party at the Election|url=http://archives.cerium.ca/IMG/pdf/Zachary_Courser_-_The_Tea_Party_at_the_Election.pdf|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Town hall meetings by teleconference or online grew in popularity. Obama held some as sitting President, starting in 2011. Federal agencies have held town halls on Twitter since at least 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.digitalgov.gov/2015/12/18/twitter-town-hall-tips-from-the-va/|title=Twitter Town Hall Tips from the VA|date=2015-12-18|website=DigitalGov|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.digitalgov.gov/2013/10/16/twitter-chats-for-federal-agencies/|title=Twitter Chat Guidance for Federal Agencies|date=2013-10-16|website=DigitalGov|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> Some politicians have held AMAs on Reddit, which have similar formats.
In 2017, constituents opposed to repeal of that same [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|health care act]] began attending town halls to express their disagreement with abolishing the legislation. In districts where elected representatives have not scheduled town halls, some constituents have publicly petitioned for meetings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gazette.com/protesters-will-hold-town-hall-meeting-for-gardner-but-hell-be-absent/article/1597323|title=Protesters will hold town hall meeting for Gardner, but he'll be absent|newspaper=Colorado Springs Gazette|access-date=2017-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.wbfo.org/post/rally-seeks-town-hall-meeting-collins|title=Rally seeks town hall meeting with Collins|last=Moran|first=Jay|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en}}</ref> Creative requests for town hall meetings include humorous flyer<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.commondreams.org/news/2017/02/21/voters-shame-cowardly-reps-town-halls-hosted-cardboard-cut-outs|title=Voters Shame Cowardly Reps with Town Halls Hosted by Cardboard Cut-Outs|newspaper=Common Dreams|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en}}</ref> and sticker campaigns<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/missing-stickers-placed-on-milk-cartons-after-lawmaker-dodges-town-halls/|title=‘Missing’ Stickers Placed on Milk Cartons After Lawmaker Dodges Town Halls|website=www.mediaite.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-21}}</ref> as well as songs.<ref>{{Citation|last=Indivisible Martin|title=Dear Brian Mast - from the People of Martin County|date=2017-02-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YytB-QesZ58|accessdate=2017-02-21}}</ref> Some constituents have held mock town halls, using a cardboard cutout or [[Empty chair debating|empty chair]], to stand in for elected representatives who decline to meet with them.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/news/politics/texas/article/ted-cruz-town-hall-houston-congress-10947876.php|title=Constituents host 'Texas Town Hall without Ted Cruz'|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.9news.com/news/local/politics/cory-gardners-cory-gardner-less-town-hall/410860626|title=Cory Gardner's Cory Gardner-less town hall|last=TEGNA|newspaper=KUSA|access-date=2017-02-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":2" />
=== Australia === Australian town hall meetings have been held by state politicians since at least the 19th century.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/legislativepower00quicrich|title=The legislative powers of the commonwealth and the states of Australia, with proposed amendments|last=Quick|first=John|last2=Australia|date=1919-01-01|publisher=Melbourne, Vic. : C. F. Maxwell; [etc., etc.]}}</ref>
=== Canada === Canadian town halls have been forums for provincial politicians to discuss issues of the day since at least the 20th century.<ref>{{Cite book|jstor=10.3138/9781442672833|title=Changing Health Care in Canada: The Romanow Papers, Volume 2|date=2004-01-01|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=9780802086181|editor-last=Forest|editor-first=Pierre-Gerlier|doi=10.3138/9781442672833|editor-last2=Marchildon|editor-first2=Gregory P.|editor-last3=Mclntosh|editor-first3=Tom}}</ref> During the 1993 elections, televised town hall meetings were one of a number of initiatives mainstream media adopted to center ordinary citizens at the heart of their campaign coverage. These efforts, which also included panels of voters to offer comment in print and on radio shows, have been collectively praised as an "international best practice."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ward|first=Ian|year=1995|title=Bringing the voters back in: A Canadian model for Australia?|url=|journal=Australian Studies of Journalism|volume=4|pages=29–49|via=}}</ref>
=== Japan === [[File:Poster advertising a Komeito town meeting 2017, on a wall in Meguro, Tokyo.JPG|thumb|A poster advertising a 2017 Komeito town hall meeting with Natsuo Yamaguchi and Yasuhiro Saitou.]] Town hall meetings, alternately referred to as タウンミーティング (''taunmiitingu'') and with the English-language phrase "town meeting," have been held in Japan since the late 1970s. In 1979 [[Shunichi Suzuki (governor)|Shunichi Suzuki]], then governor of [[Tokyo]], held a town hall meeting, its name and format inspired by President Carter's 1977 televised town hall. In subsequent years, media conglomerate [[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] has organized town hall meetings with both Japanese and foreign politicians. Various governmental agencies have also held town halls, including the Cabinet Office (National Dialogue of the Town Meeting Koizumi Cabinet), Ministry of Foreign Affairs (ODA Town Meeting), and the Ministry of the Environment (Septic Town Meeting), among others. Political parties, such as the [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|LDP]], [[Democratic Party of Japan|Democratic Party]], [[Komeito]], and [[Japanese Communist Party]], also hold town hall meetings.
The format extends beyond governmental administration and political parties. Other examples include the Athlete Town Meeting held by the [[Japanese Olympic Committee]], the JAXA Town Meeting held by the [[JAXA|Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency]], and the Intellectual Property Town Meeting held by the [[Japan Patent Attorneys Association]].
==Format==
The purpose of town hall meetings is for local and regional officials to hear the community's views on public issues.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://participedia.net/en/methods/new-england-town-meetings |title=New England Town Hall Meetings}}</ref>
There have been no specific rules or guidelines for holding a town hall meeting.<ref name="Real"/> The format of the meetings can vary. Usually, the person holding the meeting (e.g. member of Congress) makes some opening remarks. Sometimes others (e.g. local leaders) will address the audience, as well. The main part of a town hall meeting tends to occur when the floor is opened up to questions and comments from the audience. Attendees generally present ideas, voice their opinions, ask questions of the public figures, elected officials, or political candidates at the town hall.<ref name="Anup" /><ref name="Williamson" /> Sometimes, the town hall meeting is televised or recorded. In recent years, town halls held by political candidates have announced and enforced rules on crowd behavior and the scope of questions that may be asked.<ref name="Anup" /><ref name="Williamson" />
If the turnout is large, and if the objective of the particular town hall meeting is to give as many people as possible an opportunity to speak, then the attendees can be broken down into smaller discussion groups. Each smaller group, in that case, appoints someone to summarize discussion of their group.
Some have explored alternative formats for town hall meetings, such as an “electronic town hall”.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF01405348?LI=true |title=Minerva: An electronic town hall | doi=10.1007/BF01405348 | volume=3 |journal=Policy Sciences |pages=457–474 | last1 = Etzioni | first1 = Amitai}}</ref> The Congress Foundation commissioned a report on online town hall meetings, which found they grew in size and importance starting in the mid-2000s.<ref>[http://www.congressfoundation.org/projects/town-hall/online-town-hall-meetings-exploring-democracy-in-the-21st-century Online Town Hall Meetings - Exploring Democracy in the 21st Century]. Congress Foundation.</ref>
===Venues=== Despite the name town hall, meetings need not take place in a town hall. They commonly take place in a range of venues, including: schools, libraries, municipal buildings, churches, etc. Generally they are held in a public space and there is no charge to attend. In a given district, town hall meetings that are organized by the district's congressional representative are often held in a variety of places across the district.
== Other uses of the term == The term "town hall meeting" is also used to describe informal corporate gatherings held to share information such as business results or personnel changes.<ref>Example: [http://www.allbusiness.com/its-time-for-a-town-hall-meeting-11550341-1.html It's Time for A Town Hall Meeting], All Business.</ref>

The '''Vermont Maple Festival''' is a food and arts celebration held at [[St. Albans (city), Vermont|St. Albans]] in the U.S. state of [[Vermont]].
The festival is a three-day event held annually over the last weekend in April. During the event, there are exhibits and demonstrations, entertainment, and a craft show all dedicated to [[maple syrup]]. It takes place to celebrate the first harvest of the year in Vermont. A pancake breakfast is also held, a parade, antiques show, and the crowning of the festivals' Maple King and Maple Queen.
